 We have some economic heavy-hitters around on the forums who will hopefully correct us all, here are some ideas.
 
 The components are simple, all around us.
 
 Wealth is not generated by a particular "model" or "ideal", it's generated by a combination of reality and human desire. For instance, realistically if we're trapped on an island, if we value our survival, food, and drinkable water, for instance, would necessarily have "high value". That is, in our hierarchy of want's/needs, survival is high on the list (often the highest). So, food and water have no inherent "value" per se, they are not "wealth", they are just elements after all, organzied in some way. But given a definition with respect to what humans want/need, food and water, in a scarce system, may indeed be "wealth". Once you've taken care of those needs, humans seem to move up a hierarchy of wants. After that, they want shelter. Shelter has value because of it's function with respect to humans (who desire it). Shelter may be found (caves), or built (human energy/time). But why would someone build a shelter if for instance, they already had one? Perhaps if someone else wanted a shelter, and had food/water, and the other person had the know-how and tools to construct shelthers, but no food and water, they would trade, and both satisfy their needs through the exchange of "property", and "labor" (slaves/automated intelligence, can be both).
 
 So, wealth is generated by the universe and it's relationship to human deisres. In capitalism you can defined them as property and labor. Natural resources can be "owned" i.e. property. Human labor is not "owned" but negotiated for. Money provides a "universal" medium for transferring property and labor, and ends up being a good measure of "wealth".
 
 Note that "the potential for increasing profit", since humans can think ahead, can then also have value (or not). For instance, if you dream up a new way to produce furniture that takes less captial investment than the status quo, that "idea" may hold value. Now, it's really "potential" wealth, in that if it's not actually transferred into real wealth, then it's not wealth. But the reality is that either it will, or will not, result in an increase in wealth, and betting on it, then becomes a function of a generic capitalist system. Investing. Persumably using wealth to drive a particular business, where you hope/predict to be rewarded through increased profits.
 
 All are just logical extensions of the way humans function, and where humans find themselves (the earth). So, to answer your question, the conjunction of labor, resources, and human desire for those things, creates wealth.
 
 -Mach

The most important thing to recognise in the discussion of this topic is that "wealth" ie "valuable things", is not a physical object, but an object subjectively evaluated. What is wealth to one may be trash to another, the untouched wilderness of earth may appear more valuable than the 21st century civilisation that has been built. There is no social entity which exist which can evaluate a change particular change as wealth destroying or wealth creating.
 
 Matter/energy is never created or destroyed, it is simply rearranged.
 
 Nevertheless whenever man acts he does so to create a state of affairs he perceives as more valuable than the alternatives.
 
 The satisfaction created by this rearrangement can either be immediate or delayed, and what we normally perceive as wealth are existing products which provide future satisfaction. For example if a man builds a car which he will enjoy for many years, we consider he has increased his wealth (and it is always his or [/i]her[/i] wealth, since value is subjective). If a man creates a hamburger, which he does enjoy, but no longer exists following its enjoyment, he has increased his satisfaction, but not his wealth, since no product exists to provide future satisfaction.
 
 Thus there are 3 components to wealth creation
 1) The "land" - the matter to be rearranged.
 2) The "labour" - the effort to be expended in the rearrangement
 3) The "entrepeneurial function" - the direction of the effort of rearrangement in such a way that it actually increases the value of the rearranged land.
 
 Of course if the wealth created is immediately consumed there is no wealth created in the long term. And so if we speak of long term wealth creation, there must exist also a low degree of time preference the willingness to delay consumption to a later date, since if wealth is created but immediately consumed, in the long run the amount of wealth will remain approximately the same.
 
 Wealth creation in the long term then relies upon the psychological phenomena of time preference. Since even if land, labour, and direction of efforts are of poor quality, if time preference is very low, in the long run wealth will increase - and even if land, labour and the entrepeneurial function are sufficiently high in quality, if time preference is high enough, all available wealth will be consumed, the determining factor of long-run wealth increase or decrease is that of time-preference.
 
 Or to put it more simply - wealth will increase in the long run if people save more than they spend.
